thread.title: Winnipeg Jets rookie Nikolaj Ehlers looks to build on his strong start | WINNIPE
thread.title_full: Winnipeg Jets rookie Nikolaj Ehlers looks to build on his strong start | WINNIPE

author: torontosun.com
title: Winnipeg Jets rookie Nikolaj Ehlers looks to build on his strong start | WINNIPE
text:
So far, Nikolaj Ehlers is living up to his advance billing.
Coming into the NHL season, there were plenty of questions surrounding how smooth the transition was going to be for the Winnipeg Jets first-round pick in 2014.
There was also plenty of excitement, given the dynamic skill set that Ehlers was bringing to the table, with his blend of breathtaking speed and finishing ability.
The consensus was that since he’d already produced consecutive 100-plus point seasons with the Halifax Mooseheads of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League, Ehlers would be given every opportunity to make the Jets.
He wasn’t going to be handed a job outright, of course, but he’d pretty much need to fall flat on his face to not get at least the nine-game look before a decision would be made on his future.
While it’s still incredibly early in the process, it’s safe to say the Jets won’t need to look at a Plan B regarding where Ehlers will end up this season.
Ehlers, 19, not only did enough to make the team – shaking off a sluggish showing at the Young Stars Classic in Penticton, B.C. — but the Danish forward has worked his way into the top-six forward group on a line with Mark Scheifele and Mathieu Perreault.
My original thinking was that Jets head coach Paul Maurice would likely start Ehlers on the third line with a couple of smart checking-line players like Adam Lowry and Alex Burmistrov, partially as a way to shelter him from some tough match-ups but also as a way to ease him into things and get his feet wet.
Ehlers would see time on the Jets’ second power-play unit and likely push his way into the top-six before the season was over, but there was no need to rush things.
However, by the end of training camp, it was becoming evident that Ehlers was ahead of the curve and ready for more.
So he was given more and through six games, Ehlers has scored his first NHL goal — a rocket over the glove of Henrik Lundqvist — and chipped in three assists for four points, leaving him tied for fourth on the Jets in scoring while launching a team-high 20 shots on goal.
Ehlers has also proven to be responsible in his own zone, which has helped him earn the trust of Maurice and allowed him to average 15 minutes and three seconds of ice time so far.
“I’m pleased with it,” said Maurice, when asked for an assessment of Ehlers’ start. “I was pleased with his training camp and his start. We’ve played some playoff teams the past few games and (I’m pleased) with his ability to handle some of those things. He’s doing his best to pick up the defensive parts of the game. Not just the way we defend or the systems that we run. There’s a learning curve to that.
“This is a completely different game than anything he’s seen before, whether it’s junior hockey or European hockey. The speed it’s played at, the size of guys you’re playing against. It’s (about) experience. Over the next three, four or five years, (Ehlers) is going to learn what he can get away with and what he can’t. It’s going to take him some time. But I’m pleased with his interest in (learning).”
Ehlers is set to face off against the Tampa Bay Lightning on Friday at MTS Centre as the Jets continue a six-game homestand.
There had been flashes of the skill prior to his first goal, but Ehlers’ confidence seems to be growing daily and is using his speed as a weapon.
Yes, there have been times when he’s been in a prime shooting position and chosen to try and thread the needle instead, but that’s part of the transition process.
“I’m getting more and more comfortable being out there,” said Ehlers. “To go out there and just play the game, instead of holding back a little bit. Of course, I have to adjust but I feel I’ve done that already. I think it’s going pretty well.”
Obviously, there’s plenty of room for growth — which is something Ehlers goes out of his way to point out in each and every interview he conducts — but the early returns have been solid.
And it’s almost certain that the best is probably yet to come.
WINNIPEG JETS
Winnipeg Jets rookie Nikolaj Ehlers looks to build on his strong start
By Ken Wiebe , Winnipeg Sun First posted: Thursday, October 22, 2015 07:21 PM EDT | Updated: Thursday, October 22, 2015 07:52 PM EDT
